titleproper.value: Guide to the Edward Carpenter Letters and Postcards <num>TAM 421</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Peter Meyer Filardo

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-31T20:18:25</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Edward Carpenter was a British socialist writer and poet, known for his advocacy of natural living, and for his writings on homosexuality and his open espousal of this identity. The collection contains letters and postcards, and printed ephemera.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Materials were separated from the Tamiment Library Manuscript Files Collection in 2004. Provenance is unknown.  The accession number associated with this collection is 2004.015.
<list><item>Adapted from Philip Taylor's "Biographical Note," at the Edward Carpenter Archive website. http://edwardcarpenter.net/index.htm</item></list>

Contains three letters to, and one letter from Bertram Lloyd (aka "Wolfie"); one letter and two postcards to Harold Munro of the Poetry Bookshop, London; three letters and nine postcards to Grant Richards of London, pertaining to Carpenter's desire to have Richards publish his <title render="italic">The Story of Eros and Psyche</title>and his <title render="italic">Iolaus: an Anthology of Friendship</title>; nine letters to Miss Annie Riley, first of Sheffield, later of Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts; a clipping from the Evening Standard noting Carpenter's 80th birthday, and a brochure from the Edward Carpenter International Memorial Trust. All the letters and postcards are signed.
